properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts reaching 15 to 20 centimetres are expected until Tuesday evening. In addition, moderate to strong easterly winds may occasionally reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T20:52:06-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow for New Year's Day A low pressure system will intensify over the Maritimes, bringing snow and strong winds over the North Shore beginning Tuesday evening into Wednesday evening. Snowfall amounts approaching 15 centimetres are possible. Visibilities could be significantly reduced in blowing snow, making travel difficult during this period of festivities. Please consider modifying non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T20:52:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T04:53:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1851343539.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, but intense snowfall expected to develop this morning. Flurries will develop early this morning. A brief period of heavy snow is expected later this morning. Strong wind gusts of up to 70 km/h are also anticipated. The combination of heavy snow and strong winds will result in reduced visibility. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T23:43:34-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A frontal system approaching southern BC will bring heavy snow to the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt. Snow will begin this evening with the snow level near 900 metres. The snow level will rise on Tuesday morning to near the summit at which point the snow will become heavy and wet. On Tuesday evening the wet snow will change to rain as the snow level rises above the summit. The highest snowfall will be near the summit with total accumulation of 20 to 30 cm expected by Tuesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T17:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T01:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1412315977.2019
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Gusty winds tonight. Gusty winds up to 65 kilometres per hour will continue over the regions through this evening and may cause further power outages due to the ice accumulation on trees and structures. The winds should gradually diminish overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 30 cm expected. Locations: all areas except southeastern New Brunswick and the Fundy coast. Time span: today to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin in the southwest this morning and spread to the northeast by this afternoon. Some southern and eastern parts of the province will see a changeover to rain tonight before tapering off to flurries on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC. Light snow will begin this evening over West Kootenay and Kootenay Pass. Snow will intensify early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 30 cm. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. The heavy snow is expected to ease overnight Tuesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T14:56:27-00:00

Area: West Kootenay

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected on New Year's Eve. Locations: central to northern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin in the southwest Tuesday morning and spread to the northeast by Tuesday afternoon. Central and eastern parts of the province could see a period of ice pellets or freezing rain or a changeover to rain late Tuesday night before tapering off to flurries on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow for the New Year... A low pressure system will intensify over the Maritimes on Wednesday, bringing 10 to 15 centimetres of snow over the northern shore and the Parc de la Gaspésie. Moderate to strong northwesterly winds will develop Wednesday afternoon and evening and will cause blowing snow over exposed areas. Accumulating snow and poor visibility will make driving conditions difficult in this period of festivities. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locations: southern as well as parts of western and central Newfoundland. Time span: overnight Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop over southwestern Newfoundland tonight and spread across the Island on Wednesday. Snow and strengthening winds could result in poor driving conditions on New Year's Day. Precipitation will likely change to rain or drizzle along the south coast and southern Avalon Peninsula by Wednesday evening. There is some uncertainty in precipitation amounts over much of the island. Areas not mentioned above will likely see between 5 and 10 cm of snow. However, higher amounts are still possible at this time. For this reason, as well as travel considerations, this statement will remain in effect for the entire island. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-01T01:04:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T09:05:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1079366682.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets changing to rain along with strong winds expected for New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 2 cm over southwestern Nova Scotia to 10 to 15 cm over Cumberland County, as well as Victoria and Inverness Counties in Cape Breton. Total rainfall: 5 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h. Locations: All of Nova Scotia. Time span: This morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow or rain is expected to develop this morning over southwestern Nova Scotia then spread to all regions of the province by this evening. Snow will mix with ice pellets and there is a risk of freezing rain before the changeover to rain. Strong southeast winds gusting to 70 to possibly 80 km/h will develop this afternoon and evening then diminish overnight. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation and strong winds could impact travel in parts of the province today and tonight especially over northern and eastern parts of the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T00:44:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T08:45:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1772330335.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC and bring snow to the region today and tonight. Over Arrow-Slocan, as well as northern portions of Kootenay Lake 15 to 25 cm is expected by Wednesday morning. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. In the Elk Valley region, areas near Fernie and Morrissey can expect upwards of 15 to 25 cm of snow this afternoon through to early Wednesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 40 cm. The heavy snow is expected to ease by Wednesday morning. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds could affect travel on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locally higher amounts possible, especially over Prince County. Maximum wind gusts: 70 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: All of Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon into early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop this afternoon and will likely mix with or changeover to ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain before changing to rain near midnight then ending early Wednesday morning. Strong east to southeast winds gusting up to 70 km/h or higher will develop this evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds will likely impact travel across the province this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T00:47:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T08:48:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3849152308.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 110 km/h overnight tonight. Near 120 km/h Wednesday. Time span: overnight tonight until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Winds will ease and shift to southwesterly Wednesday afternoon. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-01T01:02:05-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A storm tracking across the northern interior this evening will continue to bring heavy snow to Pine Pass and Williston. 5 to 9 cm of snow has fallen over the region. Additional 5 to 10 cm snowfall is expected tonight. Snow will taper off to a few flurries or rain showers early Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T16:28:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T00:29:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3625003982.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC and bring snow to the region today and tonight. Over Arrow-Slocan, as well as northern portions of Kootenay Lake 15 to 25 cm is expected by Wednesday morning. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. In the Elk Valley region, areas near Fernie and Morrissey can expect upwards of 15 to 25 cm of snow this afternoon through to early Wednesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 40 cm. The heavy snow is expected to ease by Wednesday morning. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T00:28:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T08:29:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1001515295.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow to make travel difficult today and tonight. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 2 to 15 mm. Locations: southeastern New Brunswick and the Fundy coast. Time span: this morning into tonight. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop this morning or afternoon. The snow will change to rain along the Fundy coast this afternoon or evening and elsewhere later tonight. The timing of the precipitation will impact travel across much of the province today and tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T00:30:07-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and strong winds expected on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 10 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total rainfall: 2 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, possibly 90 km/h. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine Time span: Late this evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop this evening and persist into the overnight period and taper to showers early Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds gusting to 80 km/h or higher will develop this evening and persist overnight before diminishing later Wednesday morning, These winds will give reduced visibility at times in blowing snow tonight. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact travel on the islands tonight or New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-01T00:45:28-00:00
